commit_message:
Update deprecated option for pci passthrough

This commit moves the deprecated pci_passthrough_whitelist option from the
[DEFAULT] section of nova.conf to the [pci] section as passthrough_whitelist.

Change-Id: I13b734e60d5155c3f695a19cda180b4a2e4c027d
Closes-Bug: #1795052
(cherry picked from commit f67e610609df9f99778de00630c7e0db9b4295ed)
Signed-off-by: Matthew Thode <mthode@mthode.org>

I'm not sure yet whether the buildimages job should be defined inside each plugin repository or be all inside sahara.git. The -base one should still leave inside sahara.git."}, {'account_id': 10459, 'date': '2019-01-21 18:26:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

you may want to update the documentation too'}, {'account_id': 8932, 'date': '2019-01-23 14:45:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 8932, 'date': '2019-01-23 14:56:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 8932, 'date': '2019-02-15 18:05:12.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 8932, 'date': '2019-02-15 18:27:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 8932, 'date': '2019-02-15 18:54:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 23078, 'date': '2019-02-17 22:11:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 10459, 'date': '2019-02-18 10:07:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

I see a failure in EDP jobs when using an Ubuntu image, but the weird thing is that the job apparently finished, but someone asks for its termination.
Compare the stderr of the job on the worker:


19/02/15 19:10:46 INFO mapred.SparkHadoopMapRedUtil: attempt_20190215191044_0002_m_000001_5: Committed
19/02/15 19:10:46 INFO executor.Executor: Finished task 1.0 in stage 2.0 (TID 5). 1627 bytes result sent to driver
19/02/15 19:10:47 INFO executor.CoarseGrainedExecutorBackend: Driver commanded a shutdown
19/02/15 19:10:47 INFO memory.MemoryStore: MemoryStore cleared


with the log on the worker:
19/02/15 19:10:31 INFO worker.ExecutorRunner: Launch command: "/usr/lib/jvm/java-8-openjdk-amd64/jre/bin/java" "-cp" "/usr/lib/hadoop-mapreduce/hadoop-openstack.jar:/opt/spark/conf/:/opt/spark/jars/*:/etc/hadoop/conf/" "-Xmx1024M" "-Dspark.driver.port=43751" "org.apache.spark.executor.CoarseGrainedExecutorBackend" "--driver-url" "spark://CoarseGrainedScheduler@192.168.100.7:43751" "--executor-id" "1" "--hostname" "192.168.100.4" "--cores" "1" "--app-id" "app-20190215191030-0000" "--worker-url" "spark://Worker@192.168.100.4:42459"
19/02/15 19:10:47 INFO worker.Worker: Asked to kill executor app-20190215191030-0000/1
19/02/15 19:10:47 INFO worker.ExecutorRunner: Runner thread for executor app-20190215191030-0000/1 interrupted

That said, I don't think that this a blocker for this job, but rather a configuration issue that can be fixed later. A CentOS 7 image does *not* show the issue, so I'm going to approve this.'}]

commit_message:
Adding Spark to sahara-image-pack

Adding the ability to create spark images using the new image
generation.

Change-Id: I220a05d782f749d3799fc37aa7d787d2fd8993b4

commit_message:
Revert "Avoid distro installing unused services"

The distro_install and service_install packages have got all
mixed up together. As a result source installs are dropping
openstack distro packages all over the place.

This reverts commit c0010010c284412799f767351e7d52973655f1ee.

Change-Id: I485ec63d7e3f750734fb07bf97aa4cdfcecae468

commit_message:
Revert "Avoid distro installing unused services"

The distro_install and service_install packages have got all
mixed up together. As a result source installs are dropping
openstack distro packages all over the place.

This reverts commit bae892d9badbca8d3a99e79ffeba71d21ed4b00b.

Change-Id: I4f0128e629abe2b16dc64d9f3d56032f2f358129

they can and cant use.'}, {'account_id': 8768, 'date': '2018-12-05 16:52:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(8 comments)

The "cpu features as traits" functionality is already present, this spec just builds on top of it to allow specifying more than one CPU model.'}, {'account_id': 8768, 'date': '2018-12-05 18:15:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 28433, 'date': '2018-12-10 16:11:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)

this spec is still pretty light on detail.
that said its a relitvly small feature but i would still expect more detail about how this is expected to be used.

e.g. an example of how the traits can be specified in the flavor and/or image metadata.

also we should not need a new scheduler filter as i said inline.

i would like to see how we calculate the traits set for the host documented too. i would assume it is the union of all traits/features listed by all enabled cpu models + the extra cpus flags config option.

direction wise im more or less ok with the suggested change.'}, {'account_id': 28433, 'date': '2018-12-11 16:37:37.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 8768, 'date': '2018-12-13 20:44:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-11-29 16:58:22.000000000', 'message': 'Select cpu model from a list of cpu models

Currently we uses cpu_model in nova.conf (when cpu_mode is set to
‘custom’) to specify the CPU model the instance should use on this host.
This could have implications on availability of compute nodes for live
migration if you ended up with an "advanced" CPU model when all you
really cared about was an older feature flag.

To mitigate the problem , we use cpu_models to replace cpu_model, where
cpu_models is an ordered list of CPU models the host supports. The list
is ordered so that the more common and less advanced CPU models are
listed earlier. End users specify CPU models they required through
traits,
libvirt driver then select the first one in the list that can provide
the required feature traits. This would make it more likely that you
could live-migrate later on.

blueprint: cpu-model-selection
Change-Id: I546230ac115eb3de14eac25b9dd0c74aafdaccd5
Signed-off-by: Jack Ding <jack.ding@windriver.com>
'}, {'created': '2018-12-10 16:11:27.000000000', 'message': 'Select cpu model from a list of cpu models

'}, {'created': '2018-12-18 23:03:00.000000000', 'message': 'Select cpu model from a list of cpu models

Currently we uses cpu_model in nova.conf (when cpu_mode is set to
‘custom’) to specify the CPU model the instance should use on this host.

migration if you ended up with an "advanced" CPU model when all you
really cared about was an older feature flag.

To mitigate the problem , we use cpu_models to replace cpu_model, where
cpu_models is an ordered list of CPU models the host supports. The list
is ordered so that the more common and less advanced CPU models are
listed earlier. End users specify CPU features they required through
traits, libvirt driver then select the first one in the list that can
provide the required feature traits. This would make it more likely that
the instance could be live-migrated later on.

commit_message:
Select cpu model from a list of cpu models

Currently we uses cpu_model in nova.conf (when cpu_mode is set to
‘custom’) to specify the CPU model the instance should use on this host.
This could have implications on availability of compute nodes for live
migration if you ended up with an "advanced" CPU model when all you
really cared about was an older feature flag.

To mitigate the problem , we use cpu_models to replace cpu_model, where
cpu_models is an ordered list of CPU models the host supports. The list
is ordered so that the more common and less advanced CPU models are
listed earlier. End users specify CPU features they required through
traits, libvirt driver then select the first one in the list that can
provide the required feature traits. This would make it more likely that
the instance could be live-migrated later on.

blueprint: cpu-model-selection
Change-Id: I546230ac115eb3de14eac25b9dd0c74aafdaccd5
Signed-off-by: Jack Ding <jack.ding@windriver.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-02-15 17:29:25.000000000', 'message': 'Cleanup inflight rpc messages between test cases

The oslo_messaging._drivers.impl_fake.FakeExchangeManager._exchanges [1]
is a dict keyed by exchange name, "nova" for the nova services, and the
value is a FakeExchange that simulate a message bus for our tests.
It is basically a queue holding messages between FakeDriver instances
running in our rpc servers.

As FakeExchangeManager._exchanges is a class level variable it does not
get re-initialized between test cases that are running in the same
process.

So one test case can put an rpc message in the exchange that gets
delivered to the rpc server in a subsequent test case. This issue
made visible by the first patch set of the patch[2]

[1] https://github.com/openstack/oslo.messaging/blob/648ad56c8652d83d3b1cae745488bb8e0450febd/oslo_messaging/_drivers/impl_fake.py#L149
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/635859/1

Change-Id: Ie60d783a970029371ec834aa26ca98252cdab83b
'}]
commit_message:
Cleanup inflight rpc messages between test cases

The oslo_messaging._drivers.impl_fake.FakeExchangeManager._exchanges [1]
is a dict keyed by exchange name, "nova" for the nova services, and the
value is a FakeExchange that simulate a message bus for our tests.
It is basically a queue holding messages between FakeDriver instances
running in our rpc servers.

As FakeExchangeManager._exchanges is a class level variable it does not
get re-initialized between test cases that are running in the same
process.

So one test case can put an rpc message in the exchange that gets
delivered to the rpc server in a subsequent test case. This issue
made visible by the first patch set of the patch[2]

[1] https://github.com/openstack/oslo.messaging/blob/648ad56c8652d83d3b1cae745488bb8e0450febd/oslo_messaging/_drivers/impl_fake.py#L149
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/635859/1

Change-Id: Ie60d783a970029371ec834aa26ca98252cdab83b

commit_message:
Update deprecated option for pci passthrough

This commit moves the deprecated pci_passthrough_whitelist option from the
[DEFAULT] section of nova.conf to the [pci] section as passthrough_whitelist.

Change-Id: I13b734e60d5155c3f695a19cda180b4a2e4c027d
Closes-Bug: #1795052
(cherry picked from commit f67e610609df9f99778de00630c7e0db9b4295ed)
Signed-off-by: Matthew Thode <mthode@mthode.org>

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-12-20 17:49:54.000000000', 'message': "Create cells before starting nova services

Nova services may reasonably expect cell databases to exist when they
start. The current cell setup tasks in kolla run after the nova
containers have started, meaning that cells may or may not exist in the
database when they start, depending on timing. In particular, we are
seeing issues in kolla CI currently with jobs timing out waiting for
nova compute services to start. The following error is seen in the nova
logs of these jobs, which may or may not be relevant:

No cells are configured, unable to continue

This change creates the cell0 and cell1 databases prior to starting nova
services.

In order to do this, we must create new containers in which to run the
nova-manage commands, because the nova-api container may not yet exist.
This required adding support to the kolla_docker module for specifying a
command for the container to run that overrides the image's command.

We also add the standard output and error to the module's result when a
non-detached container is run. A secondary benefit of this is that the
output of bootstrap containers is now displayed in the Ansible output if
the bootstrapping command fails, which will help with debugging.

Change-Id: I2c1e991064f9f588f398ccbabda94f69dc285e61
Closes-Bug: #1808575
(cherry picked from commit 365bb5177ddc044e567f91c579aa2a85d6592bb9)

commit_message:
Create cells before starting nova services

Nova services may reasonably expect cell databases to exist when they
start. The current cell setup tasks in kolla run after the nova
containers have started, meaning that cells may or may not exist in the
database when they start, depending on timing. In particular, we are
seeing issues in kolla CI currently with jobs timing out waiting for
nova compute services to start. The following error is seen in the nova
logs of these jobs, which may or may not be relevant:

No cells are configured, unable to continue

This change creates the cell0 and cell1 databases prior to starting nova
services.

In order to do this, we must create new containers in which to run the
nova-manage commands, because the nova-api container may not yet exist.
This required adding support to the kolla_docker module for specifying a
command for the container to run that overrides the image's command.

We also add the standard output and error to the module's result when a
non-detached container is run. A secondary benefit of this is that the
output of bootstrap containers is now displayed in the Ansible output if
the bootstrapping command fails, which will help with debugging.

Change-Id: I2c1e991064f9f588f398ccbabda94f69dc285e61
Closes-Bug: #1808575
(cherry picked from commit 365bb5177ddc044e567f91c579aa2a85d6592bb9)

commit_message:
Create cells before starting nova services

Nova services may reasonably expect cell databases to exist when they
start. The current cell setup tasks in kolla run after the nova
containers have started, meaning that cells may or may not exist in the
database when they start, depending on timing. In particular, we are
seeing issues in kolla CI currently with jobs timing out waiting for
nova compute services to start. The following error is seen in the nova
logs of these jobs, which may or may not be relevant:

No cells are configured, unable to continue

This change creates the cell0 and cell1 databases prior to starting nova
services.

In order to do this, we must create new containers in which to run the
nova-manage commands, because the nova-api container may not yet exist.
This required adding support to the kolla_docker module for specifying a
command for the container to run that overrides the image's command.

We also add the standard output and error to the module's result when a
non-detached container is run. A secondary benefit of this is that the
output of bootstrap containers is now displayed in the Ansible output if
the bootstrapping command fails, which will help with debugging.

Change-Id: I2c1e991064f9f588f398ccbabda94f69dc285e61
Closes-Bug: #1808575
(cherry picked from commit 365bb5177ddc044e567f91c579aa2a85d6592bb9)

commit_message:
Do not use VitrageError exception

It's safe to not catch original exception if rollback to default
template failed.

Change-Id: Ibe7ec303393a229dc166b2dbc4746ec581574d9c
Story: #2004053
Task: #27059

commit_message:
Do not use vitrage.utils.file module

We don't need vitrage dependency to load yaml files for tests.

Change-Id: Ie711b9cdafae8e80a476a6b4617d4a0a62e6033b
Story: #2004053
Task: #27059

Change-Id: I8cce42b60897e4ceb8d3b0bd5181fda88b10c2b8
"}, {'created': '2019-02-15 02:32:05.000000000', 'message': "Fix MariaDB bootstrap issues on CentOS

commit_message:
Fix MariaDB bootstrap issues on CentOS

Those issues intermittently show up in various branches,
in all cases it's wrong path used to resolveip binary.
Similar to the recent kolla-ansible-ubuntu-source job failures.

Change-Id: I8cce42b60897e4ceb8d3b0bd5181fda88b10c2b8

need to be removed

- gate-glance-pep8-constraints http://logs.openstack.org/65/269965/1/check/gate-glance-pep8-constraints/3a9db07/ : SUCCESS in 2m 34s (non-voting)'}, {'account_id': 7350, 'date': '2016-01-21 11:38:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

I am not sure this is a good idea.

Let's say my cloud has 2 images called "Ubuntu 14" and "Ubuntu 14.1". If I "nova boot --image "Ubuntu 14"", with this patch, it will fail because 2 images will match.'}, {'account_id': 17116, 'date': '2016-01-21 11:48:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

I agree with Jordan that this could have unintended consequences.

Also it affects the v1 API. Which I don't thing should have modifications of this scale."}, {'account_id': 17814, 'date': '2016-01-21 12:18:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

So what about this change？First accurate query, if no results re fuzzy matching.Then It can be used on both sides.@Jordan Pittier,@Niall Bunting'}, {'account_id': 7350, 'date': '2016-01-21 12:29:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I am not sure this is better. This behavior will come as a surprise to many users. If the requested image doesn"t exist, we should say so loudly, not try to guess and find the best match.

I am not sure what you try to accomplish here, if a user is not sure about the name of an image, he should do a "glance image-list" first.'}, {'account_id': 17814, 'date': '2016-01-21 12:35:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I would like to make this change because of other modules to support fuzzy query such as murano.And this is friendly for users who use horizon.'}, {'account_id': 17814, 'date': '2016-01-21 12:44:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Openstack users are more in the use of horizon rather than the command line, In my opinion this change is useful.@Jordan Pittier'}, {'account_id': 17814, 'date': '2016-01-21 13:22:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Maybe what I said is not clear.I found this bug in horizon when I was searching for images.If there are hundreds of images,does not support fuzzy query will make the user feel very troublesome.My English is not good,please
bear with me.@Jordan Pittier,@Niall Bunting'}, {'account_id': 17814, 'date': '2016-01-22 08:27:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

commit_message:
Filter the image with the name should support fuzzy matching

  Now filter the image with the name support fuzzy matching.
First,it will use the name to match the image accurately.If the
result is empty,it will use fuzzy match to display all the images
that contain the name.

Change-Id: I78cc8aedaa17c49fb7b265a2148a85a05fadafa2
Partially-Implements: blueprint image-filter-fuzzy-matching

commit_message:
Update dogpile.cache to match global requirements

The pin below 0.7 has been removed from global and openstacksdk now.
This will allow oslo.cache consumers to use a newer release.

Change-Id: I6d72ba160b23c9c3a3bea06a0b95c4778163e41e

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-12-13 21:55:46.000000000', 'message': 'Fix DeprecationWarnings for RequestContext.tenant/user usage

RequestContext.tenant and user fields are deprecated in favor
of project_id and user_id respectively.

This change modifies the glance.context.RequestContext constructor
to transition usage of tenant/user to project_id/user_id until
all tests are moved over to the new attributes. Runtime usage of
the old fiels is updated.

To prevent new code from using the deprecated fields, a warnings
filter is added which will make tests fail if they hit code using
the old fields.

Change-Id: I351380840308a24769ece93abc6d1a9a6d6aa06f
'}, {'created': '2018-12-17 20:47:23.000000000', 'message': 'Fix DeprecationWarnings for RequestContext.tenant/user usage

commit_message:
Fix DeprecationWarnings for RequestContext.tenant/user usage

RequestContext.tenant and user fields are deprecated in favor
of project_id and user_id respectively.

This change modifies the glance.context.RequestContext constructor
to transition usage of tenant/user to project_id/user_id until
all tests are moved over to the new attributes. Runtime usage of
the old fiels is updated.

To prevent new code from using the deprecated fields, a warnings
filter is added which will make tests fail if they hit code using
the old fields.

Co-Authored-By: Abhishek Kekane <akekane@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I351380840308a24769ece93abc6d1a9a6d6aa06f

commit_message:
properly convey Keystone v3 params

To properly support Keystone V3, we must also properly convey the
domain information to the underlaying Keystone client.

Change-Id: I725e107e418d15b65aabf24f8c05403f952f94d5
story: 2005018
Task: 29497
(cherry picked from commit be58b5b95b6047c9009f99d45ac1a85d0376adcb)

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-01-23 09:41:27.000000000', 'message': 'Add description field to node

This patch implements the feature of storing informational free-form text
into ironic node, via the "description" field.

commit_message:
Add description field to node

This patch implements the feature of storing informational free-form text
into ironic node, via the "description" field.

Operators can do simple queries on the context of description.

Change-Id: I787fb0df34566aff30dea4c4a3ba0e1ec820d044
Story: 2003089
Task: 23178

commit_message:
Introduce container_cli hiera key

This hiera key is useful for when scripts want to figure out what tool
to call. This way they only need to call hiera in order to figure that
out.

Change-Id: I63dfd339a68ee1730e84cdcc32856f2fb4590cf4
(cherry picked from commit aaad5025e2b98a7597a0421bf23913974f8c8831)

commit_message:
Introduce container_cli hiera key

This hiera key is useful for when scripts want to figure out what tool
to call. This way they only need to call hiera in order to figure that
out.

Change-Id: I63dfd339a68ee1730e84cdcc32856f2fb4590cf4
(cherry picked from commit aaad5025e2b98a7597a0421bf23913974f8c8831)

commit_message:
Add disk size to the flavors

Nova has added a default policy
os_compute_api:servers:create:zero_disk_flavor to admin-only,
that will prevent non-admins from creating image-backed servers
with a flavor that has disk=0 which is potential a security
exposure.

Add appropriate disk size to flavors we use in tests.

Change-Id: I9c0af0b40fc5b5c33de7f0c690d156ed2bac2f15

commit_message:
Remove save directory creation

The save directory was moved to nova_compute_kvm_install
and setup as a symlink. For that reason,  we don't need
to create this folder in nova_pre_install.

Change-Id: I0ebd3958fb3f1f323f5627e8f0ef5feb783f7a1b

commit_message:
Add nova_user_pip_packages variable

With this variable, users would be able to extend
the list of pip packages in case of needing an
extra pip package.

Currently if we need an extra pip package we need
to override the existing list.

Depends-On: Idbf2bbbdfb0d2c5c3b440ad37004f5768328e7a6

Change-Id: I7649b3b41bb8f1ae84f51fcb3149dae16501709a

last release into account. This commit changes the default policies
to rely on the ``member`` role to update identity providers.

commit_message:
Add idp tests for system member role

From keystone's perspective, the ``member`` and ``reader`` roles are
effectively the same, isolating writable idp operations to the
``admin`` role.

This commit adds explicit testing to make sure the ``member`` role is
allowed to perform readable and not writable idp operations.
Subsequent patches will incorporate:

 - system admin functionality
 - domain users test coverage
 - project users test coverage

 Related-Bug: 1804517
 Related-Bug: 1804516

Change-Id: Ib738c18380f567d0a0b24e218350c9e1cd33691f

There seems to be a legitimate error in the apache logs:

 [Thu Jan 31 12:33:18.334389 2019] [mod_shib:error] [pid 10349] [client 10.211.3.67:36244] Unable to locate metadata for identity provider (https://idp.example.org/idp/shibboleth)

Not sure where that entity ID is coming from...'}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2019-01-31 14:14:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

 > provider (https://idp.example.org/idp/shibboleth)
 > 
 > Not sure where that entity ID is coming from...

https://idp.example.org/idp/shibboleth seems to be the default entity ID in the shibboleth2 package, so for some reason either copying our custom shibboleth2.xml isn't working or the shibd restart isn't picking up the change"}, {'account_id': 27621, 'date': '2019-02-07 06:40:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

Experimental means it is only triggered explicitly by a comment on the patch. This is the first step towards adding a voting job. This allows iteration without consuming a ton of gate resources on unrelated patches.

It is expected that the new job will fail and need work.'}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2019-02-14 14:25:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

commit_message:
Add OpenSUSE support in devstack federation plugin

Modify the install_federation function for adding Shibboleth
installation for OpenSUSE in federation.sh, and also modify
uninstall_federation function for removing Shibboleth packages
when running `./unstack.sh`.

Partial-bug: #1757000

Change-Id: Ic3e0c37cff4d0dd3336521bac13da550fa6edfcf

commit_message:
Add hidden flag to cluster template

Add a new hidden flag to cluster templates. This allows an operator to
keep a cluster public (accessible to all users) while not showing them
in cluster template listing.

Story: 2004941
Task: 29342

Change-Id: Ia2717ca960041753f6e772bf2d41c7f5a196dae6

commit_message:
Fix distro detection for SUSE Linux Enterprise

On SUSE Linux Enterprise distributions, lsb_release -i typically
returns "SUSE" not "SUSE LINUX" as the vendor string.

To avoid duplication of the same regular expressions in multiple
places, add is_opensuse() and is_sle() helper functions, and modify
is_suse to invoke those.

This may also be helpful in the future for distinguishing some corner
cases where things are handled differently between openSUSE and SLE.

Change-Id: I43bf163bc963758ddbb6289928837f5f6512f265

commit_message:
Fix the neutron-lbaas-to-octavia-migration job

It appears we missed the placement project in the required-projects
block for this periodic job. This patch corrects that.

A patch[1] changed the behavior for the VIP port security group migration.
This patch updates the test job to reflect that change.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/592471/

Change-Id: I6a097822f60e41c5265a2eb8bc53509fa46400e5

subject: Speed up pylint by using multiple cores
messages:
[{'account_id': 11628, 'date': '2019-02-16 03:06:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 6469, 'date': '2019-02-16 09:57:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Mostly nit-picking: why 6?

I notice minimal time improvements on an 2-core/4-thread CPU system.

no -j
1m14.354s
1m15.541s
1m12.624s

-j 0 (defaults to # of CPU threads, 4 in my machine)
1m4.031s
1m1.958s
1m3.723s

-j 2
1m4.062s
1m1.052s
1m1.047s

-j 4 (same as -j 0 in my test machine)
1m4.214s
1m3.409s
1m2.431s

-j 6
1m10.810s
1m8.805s
1m10.354s'}, {'account_id': 10273, 'date': '2019-02-16 11:57:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

yeah, so, maybe -j0 would be a better bet, so it can auto-adjust to the machine it's on, rather than sticking it at an arbitrary number?"}, {'account_id': 11628, 'date': '2019-02-16 18:50:41.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 11628, 'date': '2019-02-16 18:51:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Ha, didn't even see the 0 option in the docs I was reading. That works for me."}, {'account_id': 6469, 'date': '2019-02-16 21:35:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2

I'm not convinced of using all cores to run pylint. The time delta on my system is somewhat negligible and could negatively impact other apps. However, we can give it a try and later revert if proven to bring more pain than joy."}, {'account_id': 2245, 'date': '2019-02-17 14:02:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 2245, 'date': '2019-02-17 14:06:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 2245, 'date': '2019-02-17 14:09:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 6469, 'date': '2019-02-17 17:57:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 6579, 'date': '2019-02-17 22:29:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

commit_message:
Speed up pylint by using multiple cores

This patch tells pylint to spawn multiple sub-processes to review the code.
The number of sub-processes is default to the number of cpu cores/threads.
On systems with multiple cores this will speed up the checks.
It adds the '-j 0' flag to the pylint run.

Change-Id: I57bb487542417ded264462996b89fbef9fc1df59

commit_message:
Ensure capsules is deleted

Starting from API version 1.32, the capsule deletion become asynchronized.
After issuing a delete request, we need to continuely check the status
and wait for the deletion to be completed.

Change-Id: I963ee2ded063417dbc4f25705adf39b977fc5171

commit_message:
Revert "Synchronize all LVM operations"

This reverts commit 206f980cc2f09610ffb86cfc7728222fd39eee4f.

This was part of troubleshooting long LVM operations.
The hope is https://review.openstack.org/#/c/625269/
actually fixes the issue since this change, at least
by itself, still had failing runs due to lvchange
operations taking longer than 60 seconds.

Change-Id: I9c3dee2ba94c3779ff43db578c59448acbcf6653

'}, {'created': '2019-01-10 14:27:19.000000000', 'message': 'WIP APIv2 client and tests

The same tests can be used against APIv1.1 or APIv2, but
not at the same time.
This Tempest plugin provides now the APIv2 Tempest client too.

Most of the tests could be ported and used with minimal changes
with APIv2, with the exception of api.test_jobs; the corresponding
new tests are under api.test_job_templates.

The tests are executed against APIv2 when a certain configuration
key is set into tempest.conf:
- data_processing.use_api_v2 for API tests (based on the Tempest client);
- data_processing.api_version_saharaclient for client and CLI tests
  (both based on python-saharaclient).

A new job (sahara-tests-tempest-v2) runs the APIv2 tempest tests.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/584110
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/622330
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/629747

commit_message:
APIv2 support for all Tempest-based tests

The same tests can be used against APIv1.1 or APIv2, but
not at the same time.
This Tempest plugin provides now a DataProcessing Tempest client
for APIv2.

Most of the tests could be ported and used with minimal changes
with APIv2, with the exception of api.test_jobs; the corresponding
new tests are under api.test_job_templates.

The tests are executed against APIv2 when a certain configuration
key is set into tempest.conf:
- data_processing.use_api_v2 for API tests (based on the Tempest client);
- data_processing.api_version_saharaclient for client and CLI tests
  (both based on python-saharaclient).

A new job (sahara-tests-tempest-v2) runs the APIv2 tempest tests.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/584110
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/581774
Story: 2004511
Task: 28237
Task: 28238
Change-Id: Ic33d4c5c550d093b305ee5931feb9f697df04ba7

commit_message:
Using wrong parameter in test_backup_ceph

Now there are same wrong usages about
'self.service._get_backup_base_name(self.backup_id, diff_format=True)'.

It should be using self.volume_id.

Change-Id: Ia349fbee03b9b29699635e1666d7460c15b6a733
Closes-Bug: #1810465

subject: Allow cascade deletion of load balancer
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 2245, 'name': 'Jacky Hu', 'email': 'hudayou@hotmail.com', 'username': 'hudayou'}, {'_account_id': 6469, 'name': 'Carlos Gonçalves', 'display_name': 'Carlos Goncalves', 'email': 'cgoncalves@redhat.com', 'username': 'cgoncalves'}, {'_account_id': 6579, 'name': 'Nir Magnezi', 'email': 'nmagnezi@redhat.com', 'username': 'nmagnezi'}, {'_account_id': 6732, 'name': 'Lingxian Kong', 'email': 'anlin.kong@gmail.com', 'username': 'kong'}, {'_account_id': 10273, 'name': 'Adam Harwell', 'email': 'flux.adam@gmail.com', 'username': 'rm_you'}, {'_account_id': 10850, 'name': 'German Eichberger', 'email': 'german.eichberger@gmail.com', 'username': 'german'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 2245, 'date': '2018-03-15 12:52:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 2245, 'date': '2018-03-15 12:53:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow-1

This requires a patched version of openstacksdk.'}, {'account_id': 2245, 'date': '2018-03-15 13:49:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: -Workflow

https://review.openstack.org/553404'}, {'account_id': 2245, 'date': '2018-03-30 02:19:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2245, 'date': '2018-04-20 00:41:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Patch Set 2 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 10273, 'date': '2018-04-20 19:17:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

We're making cascade-delete the default? Does it even ask the user?
IMO this should be an option, but not default. What do others think?"}, {'account_id': 2245, 'date': '2018-04-22 01:04:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Actually the user was prompted to confirm the operation:
You have selected \"%s\". Deleted load balancer is not recoverable.

 > We're making cascade-delete the default? Does it even ask the user?
 > IMO this should be an option, but not default. What do others
 > think?

 > We're making cascade-delete the default? Does it even ask the user?
 > IMO this should be an option, but not default. What do others
 > think?'}, {'account_id': 6732, 'date': '2018-09-17 04:39:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Anyone still working on this? Our customer is asking for this kind of fix. From the user's perspective, cascade delete should be the default option when the user clicks the delete button. We should show the warning message and give users the choice to unclick cascade delete or not."}, {'account_id': 2245, 'date': '2018-09-17 05:30:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> Anyone still working on this? Our customer is asking for this kind
 > of fix. From the user's perspective, cascade delete should be the
 > default option when the user clicks the delete button. We should
 > show the warning message and give users the choice to unclick
 > cascade delete or not.

Have you tried this patch? It should allow you to cancel the deletion before you decide to do it and prompt with the following warning:
You have selected \"%s\". Deleted load balancer is not recoverable.'}, {'account_id': 6469, 'date': '2018-10-08 09:27:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

I haven't tested at this point but sounds reasonable to delete cascade by default assuming there's indeed a warning message. Perhaps folks would like this patch better if the warning would be more explicit by mentioning it is a delete cascade operation...?"}, {'account_id': 10850, 'date': '2018-12-06 20:24:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 6579, 'date': '2018-12-10 09:04:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

Just tested this: https://pasteboard.co/HR3IkXF.png
Worked okay for me, but I think we should indeed say something about it in the warning message, since this is a (welcomed) change of behavior.

we do specify something for the CLI option, so maybe something in that spirit:

$ openstack help loadbalancer delete
usage: openstack loadbalancer delete [-h] [--cascade] <load_balancer>

Delete a load balancer

positional arguments:
  <load_balancer>  Load balancers to delete (name or ID)

optional arguments:
  -h, --help       show this help message and exit
  --cascade        Cascade the delete to all child elements of the load
                   balancer.'}, {'account_id': 6579, 'date': '2019-02-13 20:41:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

@Jacky,

We discussed this in the weekly IRC:
The decision is:

1. We should indeed change the default to cascade delete as proposed in this patch.
2. A warning text should be added to indicate that this deletion will delete all of the sub-resources.
3. A release note should be added to show the change of the default behavior.

Let me know if you need help with this.'}, {'account_id': 2245, 'date': '2019-02-14 13:39:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> @Jacky,
 > 
 > We discussed this in the weekly IRC:
 > The decision is:
 > 
 > 1. We should indeed change the default to cascade delete as
 > proposed in this patch.
 > 2. A warning text should be added to indicate that this deletion
 > will delete all of the sub-resources.
 > 3. A release note should be added to show the change of the default
 > behavior.
 > 
 > Let me know if you need help with this.

commit_message:
Remove region policies from policy.v3cloudsample.json

By incorporating system-scope and default roles, we've effectively
made these policies obsolete. We can simplify what we maintain and
provide a more consistent, unified view of default region behavior
by removing them.

Change-Id: I0f982d71fc4a5d33ed66cb34d7388f3c4655e3ef
Closes-Bug: 1804292

commit_message:
Add tests for project users interacting with regions

This commit introduces some tests that show how project users
are expected to behave with the regions API. A subsequent patch
will clean up the now obsolete policies in the v3.cloudsample.json
policy file.

Change-Id: I3f2fa736019eb143a4747e708b948660a8567705
Related-Bug: 1804292

(5 comments)

So normally we would add some code, and then land the microversion bump at the end to enable hitting that new code. This is a little backwards, but I assume the goal here is to open the possibility that we return those things (which should only be in the case of a fault) and then start handling faults to do this better.

I think I can get behind this, but on the other side, this reno and docs day that a cell being down will result in shell instances, but that's not the case until/unless we merge a patch later in the series.

Is it harder to land this last and just keep the failure as a 500 until then? What do other people think about this?"}, {'account_id': 26936, 'date': '2018-08-21 14:52:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

(3 comments)

> (5 comments)
 > 
 > So normally we would add some code, and then land the microversion
 > bump at the end to enable hitting that new code.

Oh I thought all the code and microversion bump was together as a single patch and hence I did this setup thinking I would squash the top three onto this later when we have them ready.

 > This is a little
 > backwards, but I assume the goal here is to open the possibility
 > that we return those things (which should only be in the case of a
 > fault) and then start handling faults to do this better.
 > 
 > I think I can get behind this, but on the other side, this reno and
 > docs day that a cell being down will result in shell instances, but
 > that's not the case until/unless we merge a patch later in the
 > series.

your right if its done separately and this lands first, it will be confusing to the users.


 > Is it harder to land this last and just keep the failure as a 500
 > until then? 

you mean skip down cells for nova list and service-list and 500 for show ? I don't mind either ways as until now I thought this and the 3 patches above this would all be squashed. Sorry for the ignorance, its my first major API change.

 > What do other people think about this?"}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2018-08-21 15:03:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> Oh I thought all the code and microversion bump was together as a
 > single patch and hence I did this setup thinking I would squash the
 > top three onto this later when we have them ready.

Well, we have to do that sometimes too, but when possible, we lay all the ground work and then "enable" it by landing the patch allowing you to request the new thing.

 > > Is it harder to land this last and just keep the failure as a 500
 > > until then?
 > 
 > you mean skip down cells for nova list and service-list and 500 for
 > show ? I don't mind either ways as until now I thought this and the
 > 3 patches above this would all be squashed. Sorry for the
 > ignorance, its my first major API change.

No worries, this is complicated. But yeah, I mean land all the code that lets us do the new behavior, but not actually do the new thing until the last patch where the user can request the partial behavior by using 2.66 (or whatever version you get).'}, {'account_id': 26936, 'date': '2018-08-21 15:18:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> > Oh I thought all the code and microversion bump was together as a

 > allowing you to request the new thing.
 > 
 > > > Is it harder to land this last and just keep the failure as a
 > 500
 > > > until then?
 > >

 > for

 > > ignorance, its my first major API change.
 > 
 > No worries, this is complicated. But yeah, I mean land all the code
 > that lets us do the new behavior, but not actually do the new thing
 > until the last patch where the user can request the partial
 > behavior by using 2.66 (or whatever version you get).

cool, I will lay out the patches that way then, with your suggestion of (failed_cell_uuids, instances_i_actually_got) as per our discussion on the IRC'}, {'account_id': 26936, 'date': '2018-08-26 21:18:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Patch Set 3 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 26515, 'date': '2018-08-26 22:44:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

I think at a minimum if you wanted to slim this down and break it apart into more digestable chunks, you could:

- split out the instance mapping object change to a separate patch
- split out the nova.compute.api change
- split out the view builder code

And then finally at the end you have the microversion handling code in the wsgi controllers which turns everything on - and that's also when the API samples and functional tests etc show up."}, {'account_id': 26936, 'date': '2019-02-06 10:10:33.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 30.'}, {'account_id': 26936, 'date': '2019-02-06 11:55:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 30:

I think this is missing some test coverage (details within) and I'm a bit worried about the search_opts filtering being too aggressive, but I kind of need to test this out in a devstack deployment where I can use the nova CLI to see how things behave when I have instances in a down cell and list_records_by_skipping_down_cells=False but I'm not (intentionally) passing any filter parameters."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-02-12 23:40:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 39:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-02-12 23:53:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 39:

Also, to simulate a down cell in devstack I changed the IP on the cell1 database connection in the cell_mappings table from 127.0.0.1 to 192.0.0.1, restarted devstack@n-api.service (to flush the cached connection in the API service), and then ran nova list. That eventually fails with a 500 error and looks like it's during the initial version negotiation in the client - it doesn't even get to the GET /servers/detail request.

This is basically the API log during the version negotiation request:

http://paste.openstack.org/show/744983/

DEBUG (session:448) REQ: curl -g -i -X GET http://199.204.45.32/compute/v2.1 -H "Accept: application/json" -H "User-Agent: python-novaclient" -H "X-Auth-Token: {SHA256}121cea354034cc9d2b715383c002e81f067eeb1207dd273ff76587143e309ae5"'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-02-12 23:56:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 39:

The client side error isn't helpful:

http://paste.openstack.org/show/744984/"}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-02-12 23:56:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 39:

Feb 12 23:54:50 downcell devstack@n-api.service[13288]: WARNING nova.objects.service [None req-e9c1b49d-437b-47f9-a28e-7d5811908b58 None None] Cell 0641a06e-4efa-4c25-acac-b92d1f9082b7 did not respond when getting minimum service version'}, {'account_id': 26515, 'date': '2019-02-13 00:38:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 39:

OK I made some changes to stop the nova-api hang.

I turned the db max_retries and retry_interval config values to 1 to stop the annoying retries and also set [upgrade_levels]/compute=rocky in nova.conf to workaround this code:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/0bed18ffbb46c4f2d0ec87e64a39188c165398eb/nova/compute/rpcapi.py#L373

Which was getting hit on every compute API object being initialized which is for most of our route handlers.

I was then able to get a partial nova list result with 2.69:

http://paste.openstack.org/show/744987/

Note this warning:

Feb 13 00:34:45 downcell devstack@n-api.service[15785]: WARNING nova.api.openstack.compute.views.servers [None req-76014247-0c3c-4758-9014-5c69f653891f demo demo] Failed to get block device mappings for cell 0641a06e-4efa-4c25-acac-b92d1f9082b7

I'm not sure why I got that, seems we shouldn't even get to that code.

Here is a "nova show" result:

stack@downcell:~$ nova show 159157c0-5b8f-4e90-b7cd-8eb452ef8660

| status                      | UNKNOWN                                                         |

| user_id                     | afc0009589f34f5bacb5208afd3c2ef5                                |
+-----------------------------+-----------------------------------------------------------------+
stack@downcell:~$ 


And this is the service-list output:

stack@downcell:~$ nova service-list
+--------------------------------------+------------------+----------+----------+---------+-------+----------------------------+-----------------+-------------+

'}, {'created': '2018-11-01 14:48:34.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: API microversion bump for handling-down-cell

This patch introduces a new API microversion which will be
used to alter the responses of ``GET /servers``, ``GET /servers/detail``,
``GET /servers/{server_id}`` and ``GET /os-services`` when a cell is
down to return minimal constructs with missing keys. It will also be used
to check the new ``os_compute_api:servers:create:cell_down`` policy to
block non-admins from being able to create servers if they already have
active servers in down cells.

Related to blueprint handling-down-cell

Change-Id: Id9f12532897912b39093f63e9286540d9029edeb

commit_message:
API microversion 2.69: Handles Down Cells

This patch introduces a new API microversion which will be
used to alter the responses of ``GET /servers``, ``GET /servers/detail``,
``GET /servers/{server_id}`` and ``GET /os-services`` when a cell is
down to return minimal constructs with missing keys.

Implements blueprint handling-down-cell

Change-Id: Id9f12532897912b39093f63e9286540d9029edeb

[{'created': '2019-02-14 21:38:28.000000000', 'message': "Fix microversion request URL

The code in the client assumes that we're hitting the
base URL. However, the manila endpoint URL isn't always

commit_message:
Fix microversion request URL

The code in the client assumes that we're hitting the
base URL. However, the manila endpoint URL isn't always
of the format HOST[:PORT]/VERSION/xyzzy. It's possible
that the endpoint URL pertains to a proxy configuration
which is of the format
HOST/PROXY/ENDPOINT/FOR/MANILA/VERSION/xyzzy.

This patch also adds logging to the microversion
request since we're using tempest's "raw_request"
which doesn't do logging for us.

Change-Id: I50906ec245b965faaba630fa4d01a8137d4bc3d5
Partial-Bug: #1815038

commit_message:
Plumbing required in servers ViewBuilder to construct partial results

This patch specifically adds the returning of the partial
results in the ViewBuilder. Note that this will be enabled in
the microversion bump patch.

Related to blueprint handling-down-cell

Change-Id: Ie101678f8b9f0e624c84a355e6a7249dfe0530c4

commit_message:
Support parameters in Vitrage templates

A new optional --params parameter was added to 'vitrage template add'
and 'vitrage template validate' APIs, to allow assigning actual values
to parameters in Vitrage templates.

Story: 2004056
Task: 29134

Depends-On: Iac163aaf6de0e029893386fc4274421df4706c4e
Change-Id: I144f6cb889be6e97e0d4cbcf1fe5820c8d38c716

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 19134, 'date': '2015-12-07 08:39:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-12-07 08:44:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Verified+1

Build succeeded (check pipeline).

- gate-vitrage-specs-docs http://docs-draft.openstack.org/20/253920/6/check/gate-vitrage-specs-docs/3cb285a//doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 2m 27s'}, {'account_id': 2419, 'date': '2016-01-07 01:30:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 19134, 'date': '2016-01-19 09:41:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 2419, 'date': '2016-03-08 05:42:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

Just a quick status update. We are starting to work on developing support for periodic notifications to better support Heat. This will most likely be implemented in the next few months. I'll keep you updated when development starts."}, {'account_id': 19134, 'date': '2016-03-08 05:48:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Great Thanks'}, {'account_id': 2419, 'date': '2016-08-04 14:33:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Just a quick update. The periodic notifications support has been added and the integration of Monasca with Heat has been significantly enhanced.

I also want to mention that we are in the process of adding a new alarm sub-expression function to Monasca, called "last". The "last" function will use the last value that is sent by a metric, to determine whether the transition the state of an alarm. A simple use case is for a metric that is sent for when a VM is up/down. If the VM is up and then goes down, a metric can be sent when that transition occurs, it doesn't have to be sent periodically, and assuming you have an alarm sub-expression set-up as "last(vm.status{}) > 0", the alarm threshold engine in Monasca will immediately transition the state, and send any notifications that are associated with the alarm. If the VM then transitions back to up, a new metric can be sent, and the alarm state will immediately transition back to OK.

At the Austin Summit we had discussed some ideas on integrating Vitrage and Monasca, and I'm hopeful that this capability can help in heading in that direction. For example, if Vitrage does the RCA and want to immediately create/transition an alarm in Monasca, it could do that.'}, {'account_id': 19159, 'date': '2016-08-07 14:24:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Hi Roland, thanks for the update.
If I got you right, you are suggesting that for example in order to raise "instance_access_at_risk" alarm on an instance, we will:
- create a dummy metric instance_access 
- define an "instance_access_at_risk" alarm that is based on this metric last value for a specific instance
- set its value to 1 
and then the alarm will be raised?'}, {'account_id': 2419, 'date': '2016-08-08 14:26:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Something like that sounds more or less correct. In Monasca, you create alarm definitions, which are sort of like templates and factories for creating alarms. When a metric is sent that matches that pattern in the alarm definition, an alarm is automatically created. The Monasca Threshold Engine is doing pattern matching on all incoming metrics. The state of the alarm is evaluating using the value of the incoming metric.

In Vitrage's case, let's say Vitrage will send a metric called "vitrage.instance_access_status" with some dimensions, such as "resource_id" which is the ID of the instance. You could also add other dimensions, such as "incident_id" or "vitrage_id", if that also made sense.

In Monasca, you could create a single alarm definition, called "Instance Access Risk", that use the metric name of "vitrage.instance_access_status" with a match_by on "resource_id". It would also use the "last" function, to immediately evaluate the state. For every metric that is sent with the name "vitrage.instance_access_status" that has a new dimension for "resource_id" an alarm will be automatically created. Basically there is a one-to-one mapping between alarms and instances.

When Vitrage identifies a problem, it would send the metric "vitrage.instance_access_status" with the value. In this case the value binary, either 0 or 1, I'm assuming. The Monasca Alarm Threshold Engine will immediately create an alarm if not already created for the instance (based on the resource_id) and put the alarm in the OK or ALARM'd state, based on the value of the metric.

I hope that explanation helps. There are other ways of handling this too.'}, {'account_id': 19159, 'date': '2016-08-09 06:00:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Thanks for the detailed explanation, I believe it should work.

I just realised that this blueprint actually describes two independant parts of vitrage-monasca integration:
- how vitrage can get alarms from monasca
- how vitrage can raise alarms in monasca
Once someone starts the implementation, it might be wise to split this blueprint into two.

I know that Vitrage team is currently busy finishing Newton tasks. If someone from Monasca is free and would like to start working on this integration, we will be happy to help. In any case, I believe your solution is suitable and we should move on in this direction.'}, {'account_id': 19134, 'date': '2019-02-17 07:33:36.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

subject: Allow schema setup nullable schema
messages:
[{'account_id': 12404, 'date': '2018-07-16 05:53:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 12404, 'date': '2018-07-16 07:42:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 12404, 'date': '2018-07-16 15:41:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 12404, 'date': '2018-07-17 04:49:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

waiting https://review.openstack.org/#/c/582969/ to land'}, {'account_id': 12404, 'date': '2018-07-17 09:41:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 12404, 'date': '2018-07-17 11:55:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2018-08-02 01:25:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(4 comments)

I see the attraction of using the word "nullable", but I'm not sure that it's the best description of what's actually happening here. In mysql, "nullable" means that you can store None as a value... here it means... something different.

It's weird that this change only applies to subproperties and is afaict ignored for top-level properties.

This will cause KeyErrors when accessing the non-nullable subproperties, whereas the properties API is designed to never raise KeyError for a property that is defined in the schema. (Although it still took years to convince people not to do self.properties.get(...) any more.)'}, {'account_id': 12404, 'date': '2018-08-06 07:06:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(2 comments)

some discussion about why we might need this

http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23heat/%23heat.2018-07-13.log.html#t2018-07-13T07:11:17'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2018-12-18 03:44:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I don't think adding a schema attribute that only applies to subproperties is the right way to address this.

The real problem here is that the NeutronResource base class's prepare_properties() method only strips out null properties at the top level, and not sub-properties. I think that should be fixed so that it works recursively on sub-properties."}, {'account_id': 12404, 'date': '2019-02-17 06:29:09.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

This patch seems not getting favor, abandon it'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-16 05:53:11.000000000', 'message': "Allow schema setup nullable schema

Allow non-nullable property, in dict or list schema, so we won't force
resource to take None as input. default value for `nullable` is True.

For example, if we have a list property `a`  which allows input a dict with
a string `b` and a list `c`. So it will looks like:
    a: [{b: str, c: [1,2,3]}]
Or if didn't provide property `c`:
    a: [{b: str, c: None}]

Now if we set `nullable` in schema like:
    C_properties: properties.Schema(
        properties.Schema.LIST,
        nullable=False,
        ),
If didn't provide property `c`, it will become
    a: [{b: str}]

Change-Id: Ifc03a712f6a1aae80ea094f52f07a3d9bb2bb28b
"}, {'created': '2018-07-16 07:42:50.000000000', 'message': "Allow schema setup nullable schema

commit_message:
Allow schema setup nullable schema

Allow non-nullable property, in dict or list schema, so we won't force
resource to take None as input. default value for `nullable` is True.

For example, if we have a list property `a`  which allows input a dict with
a string `b` and a list `c`. So it will looks like:
    a: [{b: str, c: [1,2,3]}]
Or if didn't provide property `c`:
    a: [{b: str, c: None}]

Now if we set `nullable` in schema like:
    C_properties: properties.Schema(
        properties.Schema.LIST,
        nullable=False,
        ),
If didn't provide property `c`, it will become
    a: [{b: str}]

Change-Id: Ifc03a712f6a1aae80ea094f52f07a3d9bb2bb28b

commit_message:
Convert systemd services to common role(s)

This removes the systemd service templates and tasks from this role and
leverages a common systemd service role instead. This change removes a
lot of code duplication across all roles all without sacrificing
features or functionality. The intention of this change is to ensure
uniformity and reduce the maintenance burden on the community when
sweeping changes are needed. The exterior role is built to be OSA
compatible and may be pulled into tree should we deem it necessary.

Change-Id: I54e3063d6e641a785377f9039641072f8001cf24

commit_message:
Increase inotify watch limit

If the inotify watch limit is exceeded then systemd is unable to
restart services. This can occur during an OSA minor upgrade, and results
in dnsmasq unable to restart on all container hosts simultaneously.

Change-Id: I77da5d99f0714975c1be025b46bb250712c78ed3
(cherry picked from commit c694cdf75f39b17b95ca8e18e13091761461cbc5)

commit_message:
Increase inotify watch limit

If the inotify watch limit is exceeded then systemd is unable to
restart services. This can occur during an OSA minor upgrade, and results
in dnsmasq unable to restart on all container hosts simultaneously.

Change-Id: I77da5d99f0714975c1be025b46bb250712c78ed3
(cherry picked from commit c694cdf75f39b17b95ca8e18e13091761461cbc5)

commit_message:
Add heat-dashboard integration tests

This patch adds basic tests to verify that heat-dashboard is
installed and could be opened.

heat-dashboard-integration-tests job is added in a
non-voting mode.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/634712
Change-Id: I2550d6fcd1ce4e05502f247e227aaec05e762fcb

commit_message:
Update messaging notification configuration

This patch add the conditional inclusion of the notification
section of the service configuration. This ensures that oslo.messaging
notifications use the correct transport for deployments that have
separate rpc and notify messaging backends. For example, if the
transport_url is not provided in the notification section of the
service configuration, the transport_url specified in the default
section will be used instead.

This patch conditionally selects the notifier driver. The noop
driver will be selected when notification publishing is disabled.
The messagingv2 driver is selected when notification publishing is
enabled.

Change-Id: Iaadc0d852c003e653e00b4736ddc28f16ddfec5a
Closes-Bug: #1794320

Socat as configured would exit on client disconnect. Since there was
no active process monitoring, the process would (a) become a zombie,

call, which makes socat persistent until it is explicitly killed.

commit_message:
ensure that socat serial proxy keeps running

Socat as configured would exit on client disconnect. Since there was
no active process monitoring, the process would (a) become a zombie,
and (b) would not restart, which would disable console access.

This commits adds the fork,max-children=1 parametesr to the socat
call, which makes socat persistent until it is explicitly killed.

Change-Id: I612cd9bca403b7a77ad3e671c1fdadd55353d5f7
Story: 2005024
Task:  29503

commit_message:
Cap capsule tests to api version 1.31

As we will introduce a new API version 1.32, existing capsule test suit
needs to be updated. This commit skips the existing capsule test suit
unless the API version is 1.31 or lower. A follow-up patch will introduce
a new test suit for API version 1.32 or later.

Change-Id: I9ab335e652f396e039dc9197c51abc4130b5a3c6

commit_message:
Ensure pool object contains the listener_id if passed

When creating a pool with an associated listener_id, sometimes the
listener_id is not set. Problem comes from [1] not setting the listeners
property on db_pool pool object even if it is passed.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/octavia/blob/master/octavia/api/v2/controllers/pool.py#L244-L245

Story: 2003833
Change-Id: I414a3c6d2e97d30ff12eda4ecf71ec032998df7d
(cherry picked from commit feff3b472c7902af3ccb4cc10f1e2ae140d66b32)

[{'created': '2018-09-18 20:39:03.000000000', 'message': 'Simplify keepalived lvsquery parsing for UDP

The healthcheck parsing can be simplified a lot, which also fixes some
testing issues on OSX.
Fix a missing mock in the amphora server tests too, which was causing
the centos distro tests to run improperly / miss.

Change-Id: I7606822b820b501cd983e8975bcb3b7d5c58d904
'}]
commit_message:
Simplify keepalived lvsquery parsing for UDP

The healthcheck parsing can be simplified a lot, which also fixes some
testing issues on OSX.
Fix a missing mock in the amphora server tests too, which was causing
the centos distro tests to run improperly / miss.

Change-Id: I7606822b820b501cd983e8975bcb3b7d5c58d904

[{'created': '2019-02-14 13:41:31.000000000', 'message': 'Ignore VolumeAttachmentNotFound exception in compute.manager

DriverVolumeBlockDevice will delete volume attachment when attach
fails, codes link:
https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/907c7d2cf/nova/virt/block_device.py#L561-L568
However, nova.compute.manager will delete it again and it will raise
VolumeAttachmentNotFound exception. This outputs an incorrect error
log and this exception should be ignored.

Change-Id: I939c09e5b0efb3b17a9855af227e6d60c64d23e2
Closes-Bug: #1812969
(cherry picked from commit 595866eb62db56fbd4f965619031ac902f99441a)
'}]
commit_message:
Ignore VolumeAttachmentNotFound exception in compute.manager

DriverVolumeBlockDevice will delete volume attachment when attach
fails, codes link:
https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/907c7d2cf/nova/virt/block_device.py#L561-L568
However, nova.compute.manager will delete it again and it will raise
VolumeAttachmentNotFound exception. This outputs an incorrect error
log and this exception should be ignored.

Change-Id: I939c09e5b0efb3b17a9855af227e6d60c64d23e2
Closes-Bug: #1812969
(cherry picked from commit 595866eb62db56fbd4f965619031ac902f99441a)

subject: Trim fake_deserialize_context in test_conductor
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 4690, 'name': 'melanie witt', 'display_name': 'melwitt', 'email': 'melwittt@gmail.com', 'username': 'melwitt'}, {'_account_id': 6873, 'name': 'Matt Riedemann', 'email': 'mriedem.os@gmail.com', 'username': 'mriedem'}, {'_account_id': 9008, 'name': 'VMware NSX CI', 'username': 'vmwareminesweeper', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 9708, 'name': 'Balazs Gibizer', 'display_name': 'gibi', 'email': 'gibizer@gmail.com', 'username': 'gibi'}, {'_account_id': 14070, 'name': 'Eric Fried', 'email': 'openstack@fried.cc', 'username': 'efried'}, {'_account_id': 14384, 'name': 'Quobyte CI', 'email': 'openstack-ci-external@quobyte.com', 'username': 'quobyteci', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 15941, 'name': 'DellEMC PowerFlex CI', 'email': 'emc.scaleio.ci@emc.com', 'username': 'emc-scaleio-ci', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 16128, 'name': 'IBM PowerVM CI', 'email': 'powervmci@linux.vnet.ibm.com', 'username': 'powervmci', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 16376, 'name': 'Intel NFV CI', 'email': 'openstack-nfv-ci@intel.com', 'username': 'intel-nfv-ci', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 23498, 'name': 'IBM zVM CI', 'email': 'zvmosci@us.ibm.com', 'username': 'zvmosci'}, {'_account_id': 26515, 'name': 'Cloudbase Nova Hyper-V CI', 'email': 'nova_hyperv_ci@cloudbasesolutions.com', 'username': 'nova_hyperv_ci'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-02-08 15:21:25.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-02-08 16:46:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow-1

Huh, looks like maybe this was masking some issues in other tests.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-02-08 17:22:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

That's bizarre. It looks to me like all you really did was remove assertions. I don't get how it could have broken things."}, {'account_id': 23498, 'date': '2019-02-12 11:14:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Testing completed on the zVM Driver CI system check-nova pipeline.  To recheck only the zVM driver plugins, submit a comment with only zvm: recheck in the comment. Contact information: zvmosci@us.ibm.com. For information see https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/ZVMDriver.

- check-nova-master http://extbasicopstackcilog01.podc.sl.edst.ibm.com/test_logs/jenkins-check-nova-master-27396 : SUCCESS in 2h 26m 12s'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2019-02-13 12:19:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2019-02-13 13:30:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

As the test does not fail alone I run a bisect to see which test cases are interfere. I found the following two where the second only fails if it runs after the first

nova.tests.unit.api.openstack.compute.test_disk_config.DiskConfigTestCaseV21.test_create_server_override_manual
nova.tests.unit.conductor.test_conductor.ConductorTaskRPCAPITestCase.test_unshelve_instance_schedule_and_rebuild_volume_backed'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2019-02-13 16:42:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

It is stranger and stranger. The first test case nova.tests.unit.api.openstack.compute.test_disk_config.DiskConfigTestCaseV21#test_create_server_override_manual indirectly() calls nova.conductor.rpcapi.ComputeTaskAPI#schedule_and_build_instances() but in that test no conductor service was started. So that rpc message wasn't processed. 
Then the second test case nova.tests.unit.conductor.test_conductor._BaseTaskTestCase#test_unshelve_instance_schedule_and_rebuild_volume_backed starts a conductor service and the rpc message from the previous test case appears and being handled. This second unexpected message causes the second test case to fail. It didn't failed before the change in this commit as the assert in the fake_deserialize_context() failed, raised exception, and stopped the message handling. 

I can prove the above by making these two test cases pass after each other if I mock nova.conductor.rpcapi.ComputeTaskAPI.schedule_and_build_instances() in the first test case.

However simply adding a such mock to the test class DiskConfigTestCaseV21 does not solve every possible failures in the whole test suite. So I assume there are other test cases that are leaving unprocessed rpc messages that can appear in later tests."}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2019-02-15 15:37:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'm a bit closer to the reason, the two consecutive test case uses the same oslo_messaging._drivers.impl_fake.FakeExchange instance and therefore the first testcase can send and rpc message to the second."}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2019-02-15 17:16:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I got the nasty bit.

oslo_messaging._drivers.impl_fake.FakeExchangeManager._exchanges [1] is a dict keyed by exchange name, "nova" for the nova services and the value is a FakeExchange that simulate a message bus for our tests (it is basically a queue holding messages between FakeDriver instances running in our rpc servers).

As FakeExchangeManager._exchanges is a class level variable it does not get re-initialized between test cases that are running in the same process. 

So the first test case puts an rpc message in the exchange that gets delivered to the rpc server in the second test case. 

Adding the a bit of cleanup to our base TestCase the interference goes away:

diff --git a/nova/tests/fixtures.py b/nova/tests/fixtures.py
index 7c910f4..e1fbd18 100644
--- a/nova/tests/fixtures.py
+++ b/nova/tests/fixtures.py
@@ -789,6 +789,11 @@ class RPCFixture(fixtures.Fixture):
             mock_gtu.return_value = None
             rpc.init(CONF)
 
+        def cleanup_in_flight_rpc_messages():
+            messaging._drivers.impl_fake.FakeExchangeManager._exchanges = {}
+
+        self.addCleanup(cleanup_in_flight_rpc_messages)
+


[1] https://github.com/openstack/oslo.messaging/blob/648ad56c8652d83d3b1cae745488bb8e0450febd/oslo_messaging/_drivers/impl_fake.py#L149'}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2019-02-15 17:21:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Bravo, gibi!'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2019-02-15 17:29:25.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Patch Set 1 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 23498, 'date': '2019-02-15 18:18:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Testing completed on the zVM Driver CI system check-nova pipeline and failed.  To recheck only the zVM driver plugins, submit a comment with only  zvm: recheck in the comment.. Contact information: zvmosci@us.ibm.com. For information see https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/ZVMDriver.

- check-nova-master http://extbasicopstackcilog01.podc.sl.edst.ibm.com/test_logs/jenkins-check-nova-master-27750 : FAILURE in 47m 38s'}, {'account_id': 26515, 'date': '2019-02-15 23:09:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Build succeeded.

- nova http://cloudbase-ci.com/nova/635859/2 : SUCCESS in 2h 42m 33s'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2019-02-16 11:18:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2

LGTM'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-02-16 18:22:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

gibi to the rescue again. Get that guy a cape.'}]

[{'created': '2019-02-08 15:21:25.000000000', 'message': 'Trim fake_deserialize_context in test_conductor

The assertions on the user_id and project_id in the
fake_deserialize_context methods do not actually
cause tests to fail if they raise MismatchError
because oslo.messaging just swallows the exception
and logs the traceback. With enough of these getting
logged it will cause subunit parser failures in the
console output because the stream is too large.

This removes the fake method and just changes the
stub to be a lambda that returns self.context which
is what fake_deserialize_context was doing minus
the project_id/user_id assertions.

commit_message:
Trim fake_deserialize_context in test_conductor

The assertions on the user_id and project_id in the
fake_deserialize_context methods do not actually
cause tests to fail if they raise MismatchError
because oslo.messaging just swallows the exception
and logs the traceback. With enough of these getting
logged it will cause subunit parser failures in the
console output because the stream is too large.

This removes the fake method and just changes the
stub to be a lambda that returns self.context which
is what fake_deserialize_context was doing minus
the project_id/user_id assertions.

Change-Id: I26b201b410aa1d965dc7a6635c11c8b63b457a71
Partial-Bug: #1813147

commit_message:
[Prometheus] Tweak K8SApiServerLatency to ignore DELETECOLLECTION

DELETECOLLECTION for some things like namespaces can be very slow.  As
it's not critical it should be safe to ignore it.

Change-Id: I513b2af45b703a73d20a98a7a770776632ae4b39

commit_message:
Docs for deploying Neutron TaaS & TaaS Dashboard plugin

Add documentation describing steps to deploy tap-as-a-service neutron
plugin as L2 Agent ext, and to deploy tap-as-a-service-dashboard
plugin in horizon.

Change-Id: I3e671d58b612a517af9cd2902401f91aad4bcd78

commit_message:
Copy Monasca charts from monasca-helm repository

As discussed in the team meeting [1] this commit copies the Monasca
charts from monasca/monasca-helm repository. The goal is to adapt these
charts to OSH standards and patterns, and then move them to
openstack-helm and openstack-helm-infra repositories accordingly.

[1] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/meetings/openstack_helm/2019/openstack_helm.2019-02-12-15.01.html

Change-Id: I261187de943046b7314ae6ab6b0f997624952d5e

commit_message:
rehome remaining common constants

This patch rehomes the remaining neutron.common.constants into
neutron-lib. All rehomed constants are put into neutron_lib.constants
except for EXT_PARENT_RESOURCE_MAPPING which lives in
neutron_lib.services.constants due to circular import refs when rehoming
it into neutron_lib.constants or neutron_lib.plugin.constants.

Change-Id: Iac637a413d398f69b1199dfe2ad16b327387a032

subject: add python 3.7 unit test job
messages:
[{'account_id': 11805, 'date': '2018-10-15 18:07:10.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2018-10-15 18:13:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-2

There are material changes between python3.5 and 3.6/3.7 in how the code itself works. I expect we will need to maintain python3.5 testing for the forseeable future, especially if we drop py2.7 testing in the near-ish term.

-2 on these changes. Chattted with zaneb in #openstack-tc and it appeears the plan is to keep py35.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2018-10-15 18:16:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Quoting from https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/stein/python3-first.html#python-3-6-unit-test-jobs

"We do not plan to update the minimum version of python 3 we support as part of this goal. Projects already running python 3.5 jobs should continue to do so."

That said, adding Python 3.7 support is obviously good. Just don't remove Python 3.5 support.'}, {'account_id': 11805, 'date': '2018-10-15 18:23:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Morgan/Zane, would you mind replying with your thoughts to the openstack-dev ML discussion titled "Enabling py37 unit tests"? I think it would just be easier to discuss there with more folks. Unfortunately I think Doug is out of the office for a bit and I've only chatted back-channel with him on this but I think we can still raise issues and discuss with others there for now. Thanks'}, {'account_id': 11805, 'date': '2018-10-15 19:44:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Workflow-1

Let's wait for this to settle: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/610708/"}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2018-10-15 21:37:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: -Code-Review

Removing -2, waiting for TC resolution(s) to land. Corey is covering the change well.'}, {'account_id': 8871, 'date': '2018-10-15 22:33:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I noticed Zuul failed, I think you hit bug(s):

- tempest-full-py3: https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1763070

If you believe we've correctly identified the failure, feel free to leave a 'recheck' comment to run the tests again.
For more details on this and other bugs, please see http://status.openstack.org/elastic-recheck/"}, {'account_id': 7730, 'date': '2019-02-14 10:19:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Patch Set 1 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 11805, 'date': '2019-02-14 13:09:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2019-02-15 08:27:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2019-02-15 19:21:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2019-02-16 12:22:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

[{'created': '2018-12-17 16:14:00.000000000', 'message': 'An alternate way to fix retype notifier test case

When we do backup for a volume, the backup notification is called
periodically, but if we do other operations (like retype operation)
in parallel, there is a possible to record the "volume.retype" and
"backup.createprogress".

This patch try to mock the send notification methods to ensure this
doesn't happen.

Cloeses-Bug: #1803648

Co-Authored-By: Rajat Dhasmana <rajatdhasmana@gmail.com>

Change-Id: I4c44cdd6a4a11a3b7b5c57ff5aac19a8d01ef124
(cherry picked from commit 593d8dfa79980db651b88957f766604240e64e76)
'}]
commit_message:
An alternate way to fix retype notifier test case

When we do backup for a volume, the backup notification is called
periodically, but if we do other operations (like retype operation)
in parallel, there is a possible to record the "volume.retype" and
"backup.createprogress".

This patch try to mock the send notification methods to ensure this
doesn't happen.

Cloeses-Bug: #1803648

Co-Authored-By: Rajat Dhasmana <rajatdhasmana@gmail.com>

Change-Id: I4c44cdd6a4a11a3b7b5c57ff5aac19a8d01ef124
(cherry picked from commit 593d8dfa79980db651b88957f766604240e64e76)

I don't think Docker hub is a source of truth for Kolla. Maybe a blueprint should be created to describe new tagging approach?"}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2018-11-19 10:35:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

commit_message:
Make the tag to master when openstack_release set to "auto"

now the kolla image has been move to docker hub[0], and image
docker has been changed to master/rocky and so on, the kolla-ansible
tag's image is not exists, so when the openstack_release is auto,
it better to use master.

[0]: https://hub.docker.com/r/kolla/ubuntu-source-cinder-volume/tags/

Change-Id: I4674ddc658ccb7cc2f982e50a3925c843c805617
Closes-Bug: #1803656

commit_message:
ReadinessProbe for OVS-DB Pod

This implementation is to add readiness probe to ovs-db pod.
The goal is to check if the db.sock is connected by executing ovs-vsctl
command to list the Open_vswitch configuration table.

Change-Id: Idd4382d95d07ffff94a30bcb7ac132b88e9d6de1

commit_message:
Add radosgateway to openstack support job

This adds the required services to the openstack-support job to
deploy ceph radosgateway with keystone auth enabled. This expands
coverage for radosgateway helm tests in the openstack-helm-infra
repository

Change-Id: I3a5505ad3d3400563694ef063b4e6777ba34c414

commit_message:
Refactor Devstack Plugin for OVN Octavia Provider Driver

This patch refactors the devstack plugin by dropping implemented
devstack modes and phases with regard to Octavia. Networking-ovn's
devstack plugin should not handle nor call out functions responsible
for installing and configuring Octavia.

Change-Id: I0eb931892406cfd4a6c24f8e22718a6caf1c08b2

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-10-16 23:52:14.000000000', 'message': '[LVM] Run filesystem check before assigning UUID

We assign a random UUID with tune2fs to snapshots
and shares created from snapshots so that they
don't conflict with the parent shares/snapshots
when both of them are being mounted.

tune2fs requires that a filesystem check be
performed "recently" before UUID assignments.
So, perform a filesystem check right away to
allow tune2fs to assign a random UUID.

Change-Id: I858a318f7a83e033cc3f2699859e38b6b74c8d24
Related-Bug: #1645751
Closes-Bug: #1798219
'}]
commit_message:
[LVM] Run filesystem check before assigning UUID

We assign a random UUID with tune2fs to snapshots
and shares created from snapshots so that they
don't conflict with the parent shares/snapshots
when both of them are being mounted.

tune2fs requires that a filesystem check be
performed "recently" before UUID assignments.
So, perform a filesystem check right away to
allow tune2fs to assign a random UUID.

Change-Id: I858a318f7a83e033cc3f2699859e38b6b74c8d24
Related-Bug: #1645751
Closes-Bug: #1798219
